facts.text: On April 3, 1961 at about 2:30 A.M., a motor vehicle fell into a ditch by the side of a highway near Edlabad, District Jalgaon.

anchor.surface_text: On April 3, 1961 at about 2-30 A.M., a motor vehicle fell into a ditch by the side of a highway near Edlabad, District Jalgaon, and all the occupants of the vehicle were injured. One Mohmad Yusuf who was in that vehicle died of the injuries.

facts.text: One Mohmad Yusuf who was in the vehicle died of the injuries.

anchor.surface_text: One Mohmad Yusuf who was in that vehicle died of the injuries. The appellant was tried before the judicial Magistrate, First Class, Bhusawal, for offences of rash and negligent driving when he was under the influence of liquor and thereby causing the death of Mohmad Yusuf and injuries to four other occupants of the motor vehicle and also for offences under the motor Vehicles Act.

facts.text: The appellant was tried before the judicial Magistrate, First Class, Bhusawal, for offences including rash and negligent driving under influence of liquor causing death and injuries, and offences under Motor Vehicles Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was tried before the judicial Magistrate, First Class, Bhusawal, for offences of rash and negligent driving when he was under the influence of liquor and thereby causing the death of Mohmad Yusuf and injuries to four other occupants of the motor vehicle and also for offences under the motor Vehicles Act.

facts.text: Trial Magistrate acquitted appellant of offences under Motor Vehicles Act and Indian Penal Code but convicted under s.66(b) Bombay Prohibition Act for consuming illicit liquor.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Magistrate held that the evidence was number sufficient to prove that the appellant was driving the motor vehicle at the time of the mishap, and acquitted the appellant of the offences under the Motor Vehicles Act and also under the Indian Penal Code. But he held that the evidence established that the appellant had at the material time companysumed illicit liquor and had thereby companymitted an offence punishable under s. 66  b  of the Bombay Prohibition Act.

facts.text: Trial Magistrate sentenced appellant to rigorous imprisonment for three months and fine of Rs. 500/-, in default two months RI.

anchor.surface_text: He accordingly companyvicted theappellant, and sentenced him to suffer rigorous imprisonment for three months and to pay a fine of Rs. 500/- and in default of payment of fine, to suffer rigorous imprisonment for two months.

facts.text: On appeal to Court of Session, conviction set aside and retrial directed due to lack of fair and full trial.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the Court of Session, the order of companyviction was set aside, and a retrial was directed, because in the view of the Court there had number been a fair and full trial. A revision application filed against the order in the High Court of Bombay was summarily dismissed.

facts.text: Revision against Sessions order dismissed by Bombay High Court on June 13, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: A revision application filed against the order in the High Court of Bombay was summarily dismissed. The appellant has appealed to this Court with special leave against the order of the High Court.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court by special leave: Criminal Appeal No. 131 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTIONCriminal Appeal No. 131 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 13, 1962, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Revision Application No. 402 of 1962.

facts.text: Early morning April 3, 1961, motor vehicle Temp. No. 170 B. M. B. fell in ditch near Edlabad, several persons including appellant injured.

anchor.surface_text: The case for the prosecution, in so far as it relates to the charge for the offence under the Bombay Prohibition Act, is briefly this Early in the morning of April 3, 1961 as a result of motor vehicle Temp. No. .170 B. M. B. falling in a ditch near Edlabad several persons including the appellant were injured.

facts.text: At about 6 a.m. on April 3, 1961, appellant reached Civil Hospital, Jalgaon.

anchor.surface_text: At about 6 a. m., the appellant reached the Civil Hospital, jalgaon. On Dr. Kulkarni, Resident Medical Officer of the Hospital informing him about the death of Mohmad Yusuf, the appellant fainted and he was admitted as an indoor patient in the Hospital.

facts.text: Appellant admitted to Civil Hospital after fainting upon news of Mohmad Yusuf's death, found smelling of alcohol.

anchor.surface_text: On Dr. Kulkarni... informing him about the death of Mohmad Yusuf, the appellant fainted and he was admitted as an indoor patient in the Hospital. On examination, the appellant was found smelling of alcohol.

facts.text: Dr. Kulkarni directed Dr. Rote to collect blood specimen from appellant at 6 a.m. April 3, 1961; phial closed and sealed.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Kulkarni thereupon directed one Dr. Rote to companylect a specimen of blood from the body of the appellant, and accordingly some venus blood was companylected in a phial. The phial was closed in the presence of Dr. Rote and sealed.

facts.text: Appellant discharged from hospital before treatment at request of companions; blood specimen remained in hospital.

anchor.surface_text: But before treatment companyld be given to the appellant, he was discharged from the Hospital at the request of some persons who accompanied him. The blood specimen remained in the Hospital.

facts.text: Police received information about mishap at 8 a.m. April 3, 1961, registered case against appellant and others under IPC, MV Act, and s.66(b) Bombay Prohibition Act upon info of intoxication.

anchor.surface_text: Information about the mishap to the motor vehicle was received by the police at Jalgaon at about 8 a. m., on that day and a case was registered against the appellant and four other persons for certain offences under the Indian Penal Code and the Motor Vehicles Act, and on receiving information that all the incumbents of the motor vehicle were at the time of the mishap in a state of intoxication, also under s. 66  b  of the Bombay Prohibition Act XXV of 1949.

facts.text: Officer sent appellant to Civil Hospital for medical examination; condition normal, second blood specimen collected at 11 a.m. April 3, sent to Chemical Analyser.

anchor.surface_text: The Officer in charge of the investigation sent the appellant to the Civil Hospital for medical examination. The companydition of the appellant was found by Dr. Kulkarni to be numbermal. A specimen of the appellants blood was again companylected at about 11 a. m., and was sent to the Chemical Analyser, for examination and report.

facts.text: On April 12, 1961, Sub-Inspector learned of first blood specimen; obtained phial with Dr. Rote's certificate dated April 13, 1961; affixed seal, sent to Chemical Examiner April 18, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: On April 12, 1961, the Sub-Inspector in charge of the investigation came to learn that a specimen of blood of the appellant had been taken by the Hospital authorities early in the morning of April 3,1961. On demand by the police officer the Medical Officer delivered the phial companytaining the blood specimen together with a certificate from Dr. Rote that a blood specimen of the appellant was companylected by him at 6 a.m., on April 3, 1961.

facts.text: Chemical Examiner found concentration of 0.069 per cent w/v ethyl alcohol in first phial, exceeding s.66(2) limit.

anchor.surface_text: On examination of the companytents of the phial it was found that there was companycentration of alcohol to the extent of 0.069 per cent w v ethyl alcohol. This companycentration being in excess of the companycentration mentioned in s. 66  2  of the Bombay Prohibition Act, a companyplaint for the offence under the Bombay Prohibition Act was also lodged against the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant admitted being in Civil Hospital early morning April 3, 1961, suffered shock on news of death, went home, mental condition not good, fell unconscious, relations gave liquid as medicine.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in his statement to the Court denied that companycentration of alcohol detected by the Chemical Examiner from the specimen taken by Dr. Rote exceeded 0.069 per cent w v. He admitted that on April 3, 1961 he was in the Civil Hospital in the early morning, that when he was told by Dr. Kulkarni about the death of Mohamad Yusuf he suffered a shock., that thereafter he went home immediately, and during that time hismental companydition was number good.

facts.text: Appellant's defence: friends administered medicinal preparation after fainting to revive him; if alcohol present, due to medicine.

anchor.surface_text: He further stated I fell unconscious. I was semi-conscious. During that time my relations and friends gave me certain liquid as a sort of medicine... The defence of the appellant therefore was that when he was informed about the death of Mohamad Yusuf he fainted and some medicinal preparation was administered to him by his friends to revive him and thereafter he was carried to the Civil Hospital.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside Trial Magistrate's order, directed Sessions Judge to hear appeal, allow prosecution additional evidence on chain of custody, etc.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly set aside the order passed by the Trial Magistrate and direct that the Sessions judge do hear the appeal and dispose of it according to law, after giving an opportunity to the prosecution to lead evidence on the matters which are indicated in the companyrse of this judgment...

facts.text: Das Gupta J. dissented, would allow appeal, acquit appellant as blood not collected per s.129A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: ss.129A and 129B provide special procedure but do not exclude general s.510 CrPC; s.129A(8) expressly saves other proof; harmonious construction; Nazir Ahmed distinguished as s.66(2) prescribes no specific proof method.

holdings.text: s.129A does not prescribe the exclusive procedure for proving blood alcohol concentration to raise presumption under s.66(2); proof possible otherwise including under s.129B(b) or s.510 CrPC.

precedents.citation: The State of Bombay F. N. Balsara  1

anchor.surface_text: The State of Bombay F. N. Balsara  1 , and it was held inter alia that cl.  b  of s. 13, in so far as it affected the companysumption or use of medicinal and toilet preparations companytaining alcohol was invalid. The Legislature of the Bombay State thereafter amended the Act by enacting s. 24A which provided a general exception in respect of toilet, medicinal and antiseptic preparations and flavouring extract, essence or syrup.

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v. F. N. Balsara
precedents.cited_proposition: clause b of section 13 invalid insofar as it affects consumption or use of medicinal and toilet preparations containing alcohol

precedents.citation: Behram Khurshed Pesikaka v. The State of Bombay  1

anchor.surface_text: Behram Khurshed Pesikaka v. The State of Bombay  1 . It was held in that case that the effect of the declaration in The state of Bombay v. F. N. Balsara  2 , that cl.  b  of s. 13 of the Bombay Prohibition Act is void under Art. 13 1  of the Constitution in so far as it effects the companysumption or use of liquid medicinal or toilet preparations companytaining alcohol is to render a part of s. 13 b  of the Bombay Prohibition Act inoperative and ineffec- tual and thus unenforceable, and that the bare circumstance that a citizen accused of an offence under s. 66 b  of the Bombay Prohibition Act is smelling of alcohol is companypatible with his innocence as well as his guilt the smell of alcohol may be due to the fact that the accused had companytravened the enforceable part of s. 13 b  of the Bombay Prohibition Act, or it may well be due to the fact that he had taken alcohol which fell under the unenforceable and inoperative part of the section.

precedents.case_name: Behram Khurshed Pesikaka v. State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: mere smell of alcohol insufficient; onus on prosecution to prove prohibited alcohol
precedents.cited_holding: bare circumstance of smelling alcohol compatible with innocence or guilt

precedents.citation: The state of Bombay v. F. N. Balsara  2

anchor.surface_text: the declaration in The state of Bombay v. F. N. Balsara  2 , that cl.  b  of s. 13 of the Bombay Prohibition Act is void under Art. 13 1  of the Constitution in so far as it effects the companysumption or use of liquid medicinal or toilet preparations companytaining alcohol is to render a part of s. 13 b  of the Bombay Prohibition Act inoperative and ineffec- tual and thus unenforceable

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v. F. N. Balsara
precedents.cited_proposition: clause b of section 13 void under Article 19(1)(g) read with Article 13(1) for medicinal/toilet preparations

anchor.surface_text: Harries, C. J.,in Ramanlal Rathi v. The State  1 , observed If at the end of a criminal prosecution the evidence leaves the Court in doubt as to the guilt of the accused the latter is entitled to a. verdict of number guilty. A retrial may be ordered when the original trial has number been satisfactory for particular reasons, for example, if evidence had been wrongly rejected which should have been admitted, or admitted when it should have been rejected, or the Court had refused to hear certain witness who should have been heard. But retrial cannot be ordered on the ground that, the prosecution did number A.I.R.  1951  Cal. 305. produce the proper evidence and did number know how to prove their case.

precedents.cited_proposition: retrial not to fill prosecution lacunae; only for serious irregularities denying fair trial

precedents.citation: Nazir Ahmed v. The King Emperor  1

anchor.surface_text: Nazir Ahmed v. The King Emperor  1 , on which strong reliance was placed by companynsel for the appellant in support of his plea that s. 129 A  1   2  and s. 129 B prescribe the only method of proving companycentration of alcohol in blood is of little assistance in this case. In that case the judicial Committee held that ss. 164 and 364 of the Code of Criminal Procedure prescribed the mode in which companyfessions are to be recorded by Magistrates when made during investigation and a companyfession before a Magistrate number recorded in the manner provided was inadmissible.

precedents.cited_proposition: where procedure prescribed for certain act, must be followed exclusively
precedents.cited_holding: confessions not recorded per ss 164/364 inadmissible

anchor.surface_text: The rule in Taylor v. Taylor  1 , on which the Judicial Committee relied has, in our judgment, numberApplication to this case. Section 66  2 , as we have already observed, does number prescribe any particular method of proof of companycentration of alcohol in the blood of a person charged with companysumption or use of an intoxicant.

precedents.cited_proposition: if power given to do thing in certain way, must be done that way or not at all

precedents.citation: Deep Chand v. The, State of Uttar Pradesh  1

anchor.surface_text: Deep Chand v. The, State of Uttar Pradesh  1  and Ch. Tikaramji v. The State Uttar Pradesh  2 . It is, difficult to regard s. 129B of the Act as so repugnant to s. 510 of the Code as to make the latter provision wholly inapplicable to trials for offences under the Bombay Prohibition Act.

precedents.case_name: Deep Chand v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: state law prevails over central law to extent of repugnancy under Article 254(2)

precedents.citation: Ch. Tikaramji v. The State Uttar Pradesh  2

anchor.surface_text: Deep Chand v. The, State of Uttar Pradesh  1  and Ch. Tikaramji v. The State Uttar Pradesh  2 . It is, difficult to regard s. 129B of the Act as so repugnant to s. 510 of the Code as to make the latter provision wholly inapplicable to trials for offences under the Bombay Prohibition Act. Section 510 is a general provision dealing with proof of reports of the Chemical Examiner in respect of matters or things duly submitted to him for examination or analysis and report.

precedents.case_name: Ch. Tikaramji v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: state law prevails only to extent of repugnancy under Article 254(2)

precedents.citation: State of Bombay  number Gujarat  v. Narandas Mangilal Aggarual  1

anchor.surface_text: State of Bombay  number Gujarat  v. Narandas Mangilal Aggarual  1 , that the burden of proving that the substances in respect of which the prohibition in s. 13 or any other section of the Chapter is alleged by the prosecution to have been companytravened, does number fall within any of the four classes mentioned in s. 24-A, is on the prosecution.

precedents.case_name: State of Gujarat v. Narandas Mangilal Aggarwal
precedents.cited_proposition: burden on prosecution to prove substance not exempted under section 24A

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly set aside the order passed by the Trial Magistrate and direct that the Sessions judge do hear the appeal and dispose of it according to law, after giving an opportunity to the prosecution to lead evidence on the matters which are indicated in the course of this judgment, the additional evidence may be taken by the Sessions judge himself or

outcome.relief_summary: Trial Magistrate's conviction order set aside; Sessions Judge directed to rehear and dispose of the appeal after permitting prosecution additional evidence on chain of custody etc., examining accused u/s 342 CrPC, opportunity to rebut, and possibly Chemical Examiner.
directions: set aside the order passed by the Trial Magistrate
Sessions judge do hear the appeal and dispose of it according to law
giving an opportunity to the prosecution to lead evidence on the matters which are indicated in the course of this judgment
the additional evidence may be taken by the Sessions judge himself or may be ordered to be recorded in the Trial Court
The accused shall be examined under s. 342 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and be given an opportunity to lead evidence in rebuttal, if he so desires

The Sessions judge may require the presence of the Chemical Examiner for examination before him or before the Magistrate, if he thinks that examination viva voce of the Chemical Examiner is necessary to do complete justice in the case
